title: How to Break Up with Someone Gently over Text

steps.title: Break-up texts get a bad rap, but there are legitimate reasons to send one.
steps.content: Break-up texts get a bad rap, but there are legitimate reasons to send one. Here’s when breaking up over text makes sense: If you haven’t made the relationship “official” yet If you’re unable to see them in person soon If you’re worried they won’t listen to you or take the news appropriately Reader Poll: We asked 949 wikiHow readers who've ended a short-term relationship, and 64% of them agreed that the best way to end the relationship is by breaking up by text. [Take Poll]

steps.title: Tell them how much you loved spending time with them.
steps.content: Tell them how much you loved spending time with them. While it won’t make them feel all the way better, it can soften the blow of a breakup just a little bit. Start your text out with something nice, like: [1] X Research source “Hey Amber! I really enjoyed spending time with you last week.” “Hi John, I’ve had a lovely time on our dates so far.”

steps.title: Tell them why you’re breaking up, but leave out unnecessary details that might be unkind.
steps.content: Tell them why you’re breaking up, but leave out unnecessary details that might be unkind. Make it clear that you don’t want to see them again, and explain the reason why. However, there’s no need to be insulting about it. [2] X Expert Source Patti Novak Williams Professional Matchmaker & Dating Coach Expert Interview. 12 January 2021. Say something like: “I just can’t see us working out long-term. We want different things, so it’s probably best we go our separate ways.” Or, “I don’t think we’re a match since we’re at different stages right now, but I wish you luck out there!”

steps.title: This puts the fault on you, not the other person.
steps.content: This puts the fault on you, not the other person. Instead of blaming your date for how they acted or what they did, tell them why it doesn’t work for you. That way, they’ll feel better about themselves and the breakup. Try something like: [3] X Research source “I just got out of a long-term thing, and so I’m not in a good emotional place to date right now.” “I’m overwhelmed with work and school right now, and I don’t have the time to commit to someone.”

steps.title: If the spark isn’t there, you may just want to be friends.
steps.content: If the spark isn’t there, you may just want to be friends. Only use this line if you actually plan on keeping up a friendship with them, though. If you like the person and you genuinely want to hang out platonically, go ahead and tell them that. [4] X Expert Source Patti Novak Williams Professional Matchmaker & Dating Coach Expert Interview. 12 January 2021. Try something like, “I really like hanging out with you, but I’m getting more of a best friends vibe than a romantic one.” “I’d love to hang out again, but platonically instead of romantically.”

steps.title: It’s an easy way to let someone down gently.
steps.content: It’s an easy way to let someone down gently. Sometimes you just don’t want to be with someone anymore because there’s no spark, and that’s okay! Be clear about your reasoning, and don’t leave any room for questions. Say something like: [5] X Research source “I had a really fun time on our date, but I’m just not feeling a connection with you.” Or, “I had such a good time on our dates, but I just didn’t feel a spark.”

steps.title: If you have different lifestyles, this is a good way to put it.
steps.content: If you have different lifestyles, this is a good way to put it. Maybe they’re a big partier and you prefer staying at home, or maybe they want to settle down and have a family and you want to travel the world. You can cut off your relationship by saying something like: [6] X Research source “I’m just not sure I see this lasting long-term. It seems like we have different goals in life, so I’m not sure we’d work out.” “You have super cool life plans, but I can’t see myself in them. It might be best if we part ways now.”

steps.title: Maybe you just aren’t ready to date anyone, and that’s okay.
steps.content: Maybe you just aren’t ready to date anyone, and that’s okay. If you went out on a few dates and realized you’re not over your ex or you just want to be single, it’s fine to tell them that. Let them know by saying something like: [7] X Research source “I realized that I’m not ready for a relationship yet. I hope you can understand.” “I need to focus on myself for now, so I think I’m going to stay single for a while.”

steps.title: Avoid saying sorry and wish the other person well instead.
steps.content: Avoid saying sorry and wish the other person well instead. You aren’t doing anything wrong when breaking up with someone. Just because you weren’t feeling a connection doesn’t mean you’re a bad person. Although it might be tempting, saying “I’m sorry” to someone as you break up with them can actually make them feel worse. [8] X Research source Saying you’re sorry can send mixed signals or lead your ex to think that you’re in the wrong.

steps.title: They might be confused as to why you’re breaking up.
steps.content: They might be confused as to why you’re breaking up. If they text you back with any questions, answer them as best you can without hurting their feelings. They have a right to know why it’s not working out, so tell the truth. [9] X Research source For instance, they might ask, “I’m confused, didn’t you have a good time?” You could answer with, “I did, but I see you as more of a friend than a romantic partner.”

steps.title: Unless you plan on staying friends, it’s best to go no contact.
steps.content: Unless you plan on staying friends, it’s best to go no contact. Texting them or hitting them up on social media could be confusing, and they might think you want to get back together. Focus on moving on and let them move on, too. [10] X Research source If they reach out to you again, it’s probably best to ignore their message.
